SENT.plain: In contrast to the usual slow disease progression in myofibrillar myopathies, patients with Bag3opathy often have a rapidly progressive and more severe phenotype with a worse prognosis
We describe a Chinese patient, born to non-consanguineous parents, who first presented at age 6 with clumsy walking and difficult climbing staircase

With a history of restrictive lung disease previously diagnosed as asthma, she progressed rapidly with proximal myopathy, rigid spine and bilateral tightening of the Achilles tendons requiring surgical elongation
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with restrictive physiology was shown by echocardiogram
Moreover, prolonged QT interval was also noted in the patient
Family history was unremarkable yet her father was incidentally found to have prolonged QT interval
Mutation analysis with genomic DNA of the proband showed heterozygous de novo known mutation c.626C>T (p.Pro209Leu) and a germline variation c.772C>T (p.Arg258Trp) in BAG3
Her father was found to be a carrier of c.772C>T
Muscle biopsy findings were suggestive of myofibrillar myopathy on light microscopy and ultrastructural studies
To our knowledge, this is the first Chinese case of Bag3opathy so far reported
